thread.title: Penn State was nearly airless in Columbus
thread.title_full: Penn State was nearly airless in Columbus

author: MIKE GROSS | Sports Writer
title: Penn State was nearly airless in Columbus
text:
Buy Now CASEY KREIDER | Staff Photographer 
Penn State quarterback Christian Hackenberg is pressured and sacked by Ohio State defensive end Joey Bosa in the second quarter. 
Penn State ran for 220 yards against Ohio State Saturday night, almost all of them by electric freshman back Saquon Barkley. 
That’s pretty good. 
The Nittany Lions threw for just 120 yards, 102 of them on two plays, 45 of them on one play less than two minutes into the game. 
That’s pretty bad. 
Quarterback Christian Hackenberg only threw it 13 times, just seven times after the first quarter, four times in the second half. 
His fourth-quarter numbers (and recall that Penn State went into the fourth down just 21-10): 1-for-2 for zero yards. 
There were some mitigating factors. 
Hackenberg was sacked five times and scrambled a couple others, so obviously those plays were called passes. The negative sack yards are the reason Penn State’s box-score rushing total is 195, not 220. 
As usual, Hack took some shots, and as usual he kept getting up. Even after sustaining a large gash on his left leg, he stayed in the game. 
After the game, he shrugged it off. 
“I just got a little banged up,’’ he said. “It’s all good.’’ 
WR Chris Godwin, responsible for both the 45-yard completion and a 56-yarder, also drew a pass interference call on a deep route, so those 15 yards amount to passing yards. 
In a key early moment while leading 3-0, Hackenberg threw a perfect ball that TE Mike Gesicki dropped for what would likely have been a 30-plus yard play. 
The Lions’ last gasp came when they had driven to the Ohio State 13, down 24-10 early in the fourth quarter. On fourth-and-two, Hackenberg was sacked after seemingly failing to see a wide-open Barkley. 
“(Barkley) was the fourth progression on the right side (of a play that looked left),’’ coach James Franklin said afterward. 
“He probably didn’t have time to get to the fourth progression.’’ 
So we’re back to it. The offensive line. Again. 
“Obviously, as an offense against a great defense, we ran the ball pretty well,’’ tackle Andrew Nelson said. 
“We need to pass protect so much better. You can put that on me all day long.’’ Tags
